Muscat, the 18th May 1937* Sultan's request for services in muscat of Mr* Yemkenmardi, Subordinate Medical Service Officer* r- In accordance with your instructions given when at Muscat last month I am writing in to you regarding the request of the Sultan,expressed in the form of a recent letter to me, to be allowed to engage the services of Yemkenmardi in his private employment* 2# Yemkenmardi left for India in November 1936 on leave after having served some nine years as Sub-Medical Officer Agency Hospital Muscat. During the last few years of his service here Yemkenmardi succeeded in becoming very much persona grata with the Sultan who now wishes to engage him on deputation from his own Department, as his personal medical attendant* 3 # I understand that x^remner who at first thought some what highly of Yemkenmardi to judge from the remarks in letters he sent in to the Residency subsequently altered his opinion and submitted certain co ifidential reports on him of an unfavourable nature* No copies of these reports can be traced in the confidential files here but it is possible that no copies were even made and that the originals are The Hon'ble Lieut.Colonel Sir Trenchard Fowle, M.C.I.fi*, C*B*L*, Political Resident in the Persian Gulf, B u s h i r e*to be found at Sabzabad* 4. From what X saw of Yemkenmardi before his departure I cannot say X was favourably impressed. Shortly after my arrival in Muscat in oune 1935 Yemkenmardi was brought up in front of me for disciplinary action by his superior officer the Agency Medical Officer ( riasy) for gross insubordination • ^asy stated at the time and my subsequent investigations confirmed this y that Yemkenmardi had become mixed up in State politics and that to advance his own interests he was intriguing against hiaay and causing mischief and bad feeling between the Sultan and his officials and the Agency Hospital. X do not think it advisaole that Yemkenmardi should be allowed to return to muscat in any capacity. 5. Yemkenmardi has some eight ye<~rs to serve before he becomes eligible for a pension from Government. Under the regulations ( article 418Cai of the Civil Service Hegulations) if he retires before the completion of his full period of service except in certain exceptional circumstances as laid down in Articles 426and 441 of Civil Service .Regulation which would not apply in this case a Government servant forfeits all claim to a pension. X do not therefore consider it in the least bit likely that Yemkenmardi would be so rash as to resign from Government service for the sake of taking on what would ue afterall a temporary employment undefc the Sultan terminable at short i notice and thus give up entirely the whole of the pension for which he has put in 23 years service. 6 . physicalDescription.extent: The papers are arranged in approximate chronological order from the front to the rear of the file. Circled serial numbers (red for received correspondence) refer to entries in the notes at the rear of the file.

Foliation: the foliation sequence (used for referencing) commences at the front cover with 1, and terminates at the inside back cover with 142; these numbers are written in pencil and are located in the top right corner of the recto side of each folio. A previous foliation sequence, which is also circled, has been superseded and therefore crossed out.

mods.abstract: This file concerns requests made to the Political Agent and Consul at Muscat by the Sultan of Muscat and Oman [Sa‘īd bin Taymūr Āl Bū Sa‘īd] for the services of a personal doctor. The file features the following principal correspondents: the Political Agent and Consul, Muscat; the Political Resident in the Persian Gulf; the Sultan of Muscat and Oman.Related matters covered in the correspondence include the following: the Sultan's initial request for the services of Dr Govind Balakrishna Yamkanmardi (spelling varies throughout the file), a former Sub-Assistant Surgeon at Muscat Hospital, now returned to India; the Political Resident's reluctance to approve the request, on the grounds of Yamkanmardi's apparent 'gross subordination' while previously employed in Muscat; a later request from the Sultan for the services of another Sub-Assistant Surgeon named Dr P B Desai; Dr Desai's unwillingness to take up the post in Muscat, on account of his wife's illness; Dr Yamkanmardi's acceptance of the post, via direct correspondence with the Sultan.The Arabic language material consists of correspondence between the Political Agent and the Sultan. There is no material covering the period 1939-1942.
